Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Communication, Trust and Leadership in Virtual Organizations and Teams

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaboration and cooperation are essential to innovation and knowledge creation, and virtual teams are a valuable tool for such collaborations. Characteristic features of virtual teams, such as the dispersion and diversity of team members and the reliance on information and communication technology rather than direct interaction, are advantageous but also pose challenges. The purpose of this project is to examine what enables teams to best meet these challenges. We use the concept of trust as an organizing principle for understanding how technostructural and social-psychological factors affect the behavior in virtual teams.

The setting for this research is a Massively Multiplayer Online Game (MMOG). Since skills required in such games are similar to those required in work organizations, MMOGs are not only useful for the study of virtual teams but is in itself a valuable education and professional development tool. Travian Games, a designer of MMOGs, has provided unique access to conduct experiments, collect behavioral data, and administer surveys. The research team will pursue two empirical investigations: a series of experiments and a large-scale correlational study involving multi-level, longitudinal data.

These studies should yield insight into the development and role of social bonds in virtual teams and the interplay between social dynamics and technostructural factors. Findings will inform literatures on leadership and group dynamics, the management of virtual organizations and information technology. Findings will also provide practical insights into how to design virtual teams and organizations to better enable collaboration and innovation. The methodology involving MMOGs is itself an innovative contribution to both science and practice, as it demonstrates a new platform for conducting social science research and provides insight into using virtual games for leadership and team development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Working in teams is risky business. Teamwork requires delegating tasks to team members, but what if a team member lacks the capability to do the task? Moreover, conflicts between individual and team interests often occur. How can team members be confident that fellow team members will “do the right thing?”  Such questions are at the heart of trust in teams.  Research shows that when individuals trust each other, they work harder, more cooperatively, and are more willing to delegate. Cultivating trust is particularly challenging in a virtual setting. It is difficult for team members to get to know each other when they are geographically separated and rely on technology to communicate. Monitoring the efforts of virtual team members is difficult, so teams are at risk that members will be unwilling or incapable of doing their job.

The purpose of this grant is to investigate how trust in virtual teams is built and its impact on key team processes and team effectiveness. Our main thesis is that trust is the lynchpin between team inputs and effectiveness. By building trust, inputs such as leadership lead to more effective and sustainable virtual teams.

We had rare opportunity to investigate these issues in an online game called Travian. We were able to acquire a massive data base of trace data, paired with surveys. We collected the data from game servers located in 23 different countries. Additionally, we had control over one game server in which we conducted a series of experiments. The results of this project produced numerous findings contributing to the theory and practice of managing teams.

Our first task was to examine the relevance of the Travian setting to work teams. A systematic review of the virtual games and teams literatures led us to conclude that the Travian setting captured essential elements of teams such as sharing common goals and specializing in different roles. Using trace data we also demonstrated that, like teams in work settings, game teams developed social networks that were essential to individual and group success.  

In a series of papers, we focused on two key inputs to trust, leadership and team member trustworthy behavior. Virtual teams use a mix of face-to-face contact and various technologies to communicate. There are no evidence-based prescriptions for how leaders can manage these communication choices. Our findings indicate that when leaders rely less on face-to-face contact, they should employ a diversity of communication channels. Doing so enhances trust and performance.  Portions of these findings were replicated in virtual work teams from a multinational direct marketing firm. Another paper examined shared leadership, wherein leadership responsibilities are distributed among team members rather than concentrated in a single leader. Past research indicates that shared leadership is positively related to performance but the processes critical to this relationship are not known.  We found shared leadership creates a denser communication network and a denser network results in higher trust, which predicted higher performance.  Another paper focused on how trust is built through specific team member actions. Team members signal trustworthiness when they demonstrate their competence, follow the rules and share resources with other team members. These cues lead to a positive trajectory for trust. These findings point to specific actions team members should take early in the life of teams to assure trust.
